definition[0]: bad behaviour, especially by children, that causes trouble or damage, but no serious harm
example[0]: Now run along, and don’t get into mischief.
example[1]: They’ve got enough toys to keep them out of mischief for a while.
example[2]: If you can’t see Nick, you can be sure he’s up to some mischief  (=behaving badly and causing trouble or damage).
definition[1]: the pleasure or enjoyment of playing tricks on people or embarrassing them
example[3]: Kiki’s eyes were bright with mischief.
definition[2]: damage or harm that is done to someone or to their property
example[4]: The jury cleared him of the charge of criminal mischief.
example[5]: The children were lively and always up to mischief.
example[6]: You spend too much time getting into mischief!
example[7]: Can I trust you to stay our of mischief for half an hour?
example[8]: Playing football helps keep him out of mischief.
example[9]: Boys were wandering around, out to cause mischief.
example[10]: Leo nodded, his eyes shining with mischief.
example[11]: I remembered him as a giggling boy who was full of mischief.
example[12]: There was a glint of mischief in her eyes.
